questions.text: A patient with right flank pain and fever has renal angle tenderness on examination. Which of the following forms the boundaries of this angle?

choices.text: Lower border of 11th rib and medial border of erector spinae
Lower border of 12th rib and medial border of erector spinae
Lower border of 11th rib and lateral border of erector spinae
Lower border of 12th rib and lateral border of erector spinae

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the renal angle tenderness are suggestive of acute pyelonephritis. The renal angle is formed by the lower border of the 12th rib and the lateral border of the erector spinae.

The lower pole of the kidney occupies this angle. Tenderness in this angle is usually suggestive of infection in and around the kidney or renal stones.

questions.text: Identify the angle shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The angle shown in the image is the costovertebral angle, formed between the lower border of the 12th rib and the vertebral column. 

Causes for pain/tenderness at the costovertebral angle include:

  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) - caused by Hantavirus.

questions.text:
Arrange the coverings of the kidney from within outwards:

1. Renal fascia
2. Fibrous capsule
3. Paranephric fat
4. Perinephric fat
questions.solution:
The 4 coverings of the kidney from within outwards are as follows:

  1. True or fibrous capsule - formed by the collagen-rich connective tissue.
  2. Perinephric fat or adipose capsule - consists of fat and occupies the space between the fibrous capsule and the renal fascia.
  3. Renal fascia
  4. Paranephric fat - occupies the space between the renal fascia and the anterior layer of the thoracolumbar fascia.

questions.text: Which of the following fascia attaches the perirenal fascia to the peritoneum?
questions.solution:
The lateroconal fascia attaches the perirenal fascia to the peritoneum. It extends from the lateral margin of perirenal fascia and attaches to the parietal peritoneum.

Option A: Gerota's fascia is the perirenal fascia. The kidney and the suprarenal gland are enclosed within anterior and posterior lamina of the perirenal fascia. The anterior lamina of the perirenal fascia blends with the connective tissue surrounding the great vessels behind the duodenum and pancreas. The posterior lamina continues as the lateroconal fascia.

Option C: Thoracolumbar fascia is a complex arrangement of multiple fascial layers in the thoracolumbar region. This fascia encloses the paraspinal muscles, quadratus lumborum muscle and the lattisimus dorsi muscle.

Option D: Treitz's fascia has been used to refer to the fusion fascia behind the head of pancreas.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form an anterior relationship with the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is the right kidney. The pylorus of the stomach is not related to the anterior surface of the right kidney.

The anterior relations of the right kidney:

Intraperitoneal
  • Right lobe of liver
  • Small intestine
Retroperitoneal 
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • 2nd part of duoednum  
  • Hepatic flexure of colon 

 The below image shows the cross-section of the abdomen at the level of kidney.

questions.text: Which of the following areas of the left kidney is separated from its relation by a peritoneal layer?
questions.solution:
The anterior surface of the left kidney in relation with the jejunal loops (marked as 2) is separated from the structure by a peritoneal layer.

As the kidneys are located retroperitoneally, intraperitoneal anterior relations are separated from it by a peritoneal layer. 

The anterior relations of the left kidney include:

Intraperitoneal
  • Stomach
  • Jejunum
  • Spleen
 Retroperitoneal
  • Left suprarenal gland
  • Pancreas
  • Splenic vessels
  • Splenic flexure and beginning of descending colon

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the marked area in the image?
questions.solution:
The marked area in the image of the left kidney is related to the stomach.

The anterior relations of the right kidney:

Intraperitoneal
  • Right lobe of liver
  • Small intestine
Retroperitoneal 
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • 2nd part of duoednum  
  • Hepatic flexure of colon 

The anterior relations of the left kidney:

Intraperitoneal
  • Stomach
  • Jejunum
  • Spleen
 Retroperitoneal
  • Left suprarenal gland
  • Pancreas
  • Splenic vessels
  • Splenic flexure and beginning of descending colon

The posterior relations of the kidneys:

  • One vessel - subcostal vessels
  • Two ligaments - medial and lateral arcuate ligaments
  • Three nerves - subcostal, iliohypogastric, and ilioinguinal nerves
  • Four muscles - diaphragm, psoas major, quadratus lumborum, and transverse abdominis.
  • The right kidney is related to the 12th rib and the left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs

questions.text: Which of the following areas of the anterior surface of the right kidney is separated by a layer of peritoneum?
questions.solution:
The anterior surface of the right kidney related to the right lobe of the liver (marked as 1) is separated by a layer of peritoneum.

As the kidneys are located retroperitoneally, intraperitoneal anterior relations are separated from it by a peritoneal layer. 

The anterior relations of the right kidney:

Intraperitoneal
  • Right lobe of liver
  • Small intestine
Retroperitoneal 
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • 2nd part of duoednum  
  • Hepatic flexure of colon

questions.text: Which of the following is not a posterior relation of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image is the left kidney. The sympathetic chain is not a posterior relation of the left kidney.

The posterior relations of the kidneys are as follows:

  • One vessel - subcostal vessels
  • Two ligaments - medial and lateral arcuate ligaments
  • Three nerves - subcostal, iliohypogastric, and ilioinguinal nerves
  • Four muscles - diaphragm, psoas major, quadratus lumborum, and transverse abdominis.
  • The right kidney is related to the 12th rib and the left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs

The below image shows the cross section of the abdomen at the level of kidney.

questions.text: What is the correct arrangement of the structures in the marked area from anterior to posterior?

choices.text: Renal artery, renal vein, renal pelvis
Renal vein, renal artery, renal pelvis
Renal pelvis, renal artery, renal vein
Renal vein, renal pelvis, renal artery

questions.solution:
The marked area is the hilum of the kidney. It contains the following structures from anterior to posterior:

  • Renal vein
  • Renal artery
  • Renal pelvis

questions.text: What is the structure into which the renal papillae open?
questions.solution:
The renal papillae open into the minor calyces.

The papilla is the conical apex of a renal pyramid, where the urine from the collecting ducts enters into the minor calyces. The minor calyces unite to form the major calyces, which further unite to form the renal pelvis.

The kidney is divided into an outer cortex and an inner medulla. The renal medulla contains many striated and conical pyramids. The base of the pyramid is peripherally located, whereas the apex is directed towards the renal sinus (hilum). The renal cortex is subcapsular and arches over the bases of the pyramids. It extends between the pyramids towards the renal sinus as renal columns.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to the nerve supply of the kidney?
questions.solution:
The coeliac plexus contributes to the nerve supply of the kidneys.

Nerve supply of the kidney:

  • Coeliac ganglion and plexus
  • Aorticorenal ganglion
  • Lowest thoracic splanchnic nerve
  • First lumbar splanchnic nerve
  • Aortic plexus

The rami from these structures form a dense network of autonomic plexus around the renal artery called the renal plexus. They control the blood flow between the cortex and medulla.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented with left flank pain, varicocele, hematuria, and headache. On examination, BP was 170/100 mm Hg. CT abdomen was done and a diagnosis of Nutcracker syndrome was made. What is the cause?

choices.text: Compression of left renal vein between abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery
Compression of  left renal vein between inferior vena cava and superior mesenteric vein
Compression of right renal vein between abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery
Compression of right renal vein between inferior vena cava and superior mesenteric vein

questions.solution:
The most likely cause is compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery. This manifests as nutcracker syndrome.

Nutcracker syndrome is characterized by left renal vein hypertension, which occurs due to the compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery. This is because the left renal vein is posterior and inferior to the superior mesenteric artery.

The left renal vein is longer than the right renal vein. It runs anterior to the aorta just below the origin of the superior mesenteric artery and drains into the inferior vena cava after crossing the midline.

Note: The left kidney is preferred in donor nephrectomy than the right because of the long course of the left renal vein.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male was brought to the emergency department with severe pain in the left flank region. CT-examination revealed occlusion of the left renal vein. The condition would impede the blood flow through all of the following veins except:
questions.solution:
The left subcostal vein does not drain into the left renal vein. It drains into the hemiazygos vein. So the occlusion of the left renal vein does not impede the blood flow in the left subcostal vein.

Veins that commonly drain into the left renal vein (which in turn drains into the IVC) are:

  • Left inferior phrenic (diaphragmatic) vein,
  • Left suprarenal (adrenal) vein,
  • Left gonadal vein

On the right side, all the above veins drain into the inferior vena cava directly.

Apart from the veins described above, the first and second left lumbar veins and hemiazygos vein may drain into the left renal vein.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not cross the midline?
questions.solution:
The left gonadal vein does not cross the midline. It is formed from the pampiniform plexus of veins and drains into the left renal vein.

The left renal vein is longer than the right renal vein and it crosses the midline anterior to the aorta. It drains directly into the inferior vena cava. The right renal vein does not cross the midline.

The accessory hemiazygous vein at T7 vertebral level crosses the midline to drain into the azygous vein.

The root of the mesentery extends across a line from the duodenojejunal flexure on the left side to the sacroiliac joint on the right side. This spans a length of 15 cm and crosses the midline in its course.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with severe pain in the lower back radiating to the pubic symphysis. Ultrasonography revealed a stone in the left ureter, measuring 3 mm in size. The stone is most likely to be lodged in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Vesicoureteric junction is the narrowest part of the ureter. This is the reason why stones as small as 2 to 3 mm get arrested in the vesicoureteric junction.

The ureter is constricted at 5 places:

  1. Pelvi-ureteric junction
  2. Brim of the lesser pelvis (as it crosses the common iliac artery)
  3. Point of crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus.
  4. Vesico-ureteric junction
  5. Opening in the lateral angle of the trigone

These are regarded as surgical constrictions of the ureter.

However, only 1, 2, and 4 are the anatomical constrictions of the ureter.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is not a posterior relation of the structure marked as X?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the ureter. Quadratus lumborum is not a posterior relation of the ureter.

Posterior relations of the ureter in the abdominal cavity are:

  • Psoas major
  • Genitofemoral nerve
  • End of the common iliac artery or beginning of the external iliac artery

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not supply the ureters?
questions.solution:
The superior mesenteric artery does not supply the ureters.

The ureter receives its blood supply from the following arteries:

  1. Renal artery
  2. Gonadal artery
  3. Common iliac artery
  4. Internal iliac artery
  5. Vesical artery
  6. Uterine artery
  7. Abdominal aorta

Among these branches, the branch from the renal artery and the branch from the inferior vesical artery are always constant.

Clinical note: The branch of the renal artery that supplies the ureter must be carefully preserved in renal transplantation to maintain good vascularity of the ureters.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not supply the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the CT abdomen is the left adrenal gland. The superior mesenteric artery does not supply the suprarenal or adrenal gland.

The adrenal gland receives its arterial supply from the superior, middle, and inferior suprarenal arteries. These arteries have some variations in their origin as follows:

Artery Usual origin

Variation in origin
Superior suprarenal Inferior phrenic artery
  • Abdominal aorta
Middle suprarenal Abdominal aorta (as lateral branches)
  • Inferior phrenic artery
  • Renal artery

Inferior suprarenal (major blood supply)

 Renal artery
  • Abdominal aorta
  • Gonadal artery

The below CT abdomen shows the right and left adrenal gland.

Related Pearl: Branches of the abdominal aorta

Branches of the abdominal aorta:

  • Anterior branches (unpaired):
    • Celiac trunk - T12
    • Superior mesenteric artery - L1
    • Inferior mesenteric artery - L3
  • Lateral branches (paired):
    • Inferior phrenic artery - T12
    • Middle suprarenal artery - T12
    • Renal artery - L1, L2
    • Gonadal artery - L2
  • Dorsal branches:
    • Lumbar artery (four pairs) - L1 to L4
    • Median sacral artery - L4

questions.text: Where does the right main adrenal vein drain into?
questions.solution:
The right main adrenal vein usually drains into the inferior vena cava.

The left main adrenal vein usually drains into the left renal vein. Variations are common on the right side, where the right adrenal vein may drain into the right inferior phrenic vein.

questions.text: During the cystoscopic evaluation of a patient with hematuria, where will you find the Mercier's bar?

choices.text: Between uvula vesicae and ureteric orifice
Between internal and external urethral orifice

questions.solution:
The Mercier's bar (interureteric bar or interureteric ridge) is a curved fold of mucous membrane between the two ureteric orifices inside the bladder.

This fold of mucous membrane is formed by the thickening of the superior border of the trigone muscle. In cystoscopy, the interureteric ridge appears as a pale band and acts as a guide to the ureteric orifices.

The mucosal fold running from the uvula vesicae to the ureteric orifice is called the Bell's bar. This fold forms the lateral borders of the trigone. It contains a band of muscle fibres called the Bell's muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae?
questions.solution:
The median lobe of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae.

Uvula vesicae is an elevation in the mucous membrane of the urinary bladder, behind the internal urethral orifice. It is often enlarged in benign prostatic hypertrophy.

questions.text: Where does the internal urethral orifice lie at birth?

choices.text: At the level of the umblicus
At the level of the lower border of symphysis pubis
At the level of the perineal body
At the level of the upper border of symphysis pubis

questions.solution:
The internal urethral orifice lies at the level of the upper border of the pubic symphysis at birth.

At birth, the bladder is an abdominal organ. But as the child grows, the blader descends, and near puberty, it becomes a pelvic organ.

In an adult, the internal urethral orifice lies 3–4 cm behind the lower part of the pubic symphysis. It corresponds to the bladder neck.

Clinical note: As the bladder lies above the symphysis pubis, we can safely perform suprapubic needle punctures to obtain urine samples in children. But in adults, this can only be done if the bladder is fully distended.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is innervated by the neurons present in Onuf's nucleus?
questions.solution:
The external urethral sphincter is innervated by the neurons present in Onuf's nucleus.

The neurons present in the lamina IX of the grey matter in spinal segments S2, S3, and S4 constitute Onuf's nucleus. These neurons contract the external urethral sphincter.

The external urethral sphincter is made up of skeletal muscle fibers. In the contracted state, they are responsible for the maintenance of urinary continence. Just before the onset of voiding the sphincter is relaxed. This happens because the neurons in the Onuf's nucleus are centrally inhibited by the brain.

The below image shows Onuf's nucleus located in the lamina IX.

 

Nerve supply of the bladder:

Parasympathetic supply Sympathetic supply
From S2, S3, and S4 spinal segments From T10, T11, T12, L1, and L2 spinal segments

Richly innervate the fundus of the bladder

Sparsely innervate the bladder neck

Richly innervate the smooth muscles around the bladder neck

Sparsely innervate the fundus of the bladder
They contract the urinary bladder and aids in the micturition They contract the internal urethral sphincter and aids in the filling of the urinary bladder

questions.text: What is the number of arterial segments in the kidney?
questions.solution:
There are five arterial segments in the kidney:

  • Apical
  • Superior
  • Middle
  • Inferior
  • Posterior

Blood supply of the kidney: The renal artery is a direct lateral branch of the abdominal aorta. Near the hilum of the kidney, the renal artery is divided into anterior and posterior divisions. These divisions are further divided into five segmental arteries (four anterior and one posterior). The segmental arteries further branch out in a hierarchy to form different arteries. Finally, the renal vein is formed which joins the inferior vena cava.
